field_edited_text.value:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route





One of the most important—perhaps the most important—factor in
our economy is the port. The Northern Route has no particular relation-
ship to the port. The Harbor Route has a very definite connection. It
runs along the northern side of the harbor and, together with the proposed
Southwest Expressway, ties together many important port-oriented facili-
ties. The Port Authority is in the best position to appraise the value of
the Harbor Route to the port. After reviewing the plans it stated: “It was
unanimously agreed by the Commissioners that the route suggested would
enhance truck traffic serving the Port of Baltimore, and that the effect
of the expressway, at the proposed location, on the development of the
Port from the standpoint of the structure occupying and/or crossing cer-
tain waterfront properties would be minimal and would be far outweighed
by the port advantage accruing by the provision of the expressway along
this particular route.”

The greatest burden on our transportation system is imposed by the
trip from home to work in the early morning and from work to home in
the late afternoon. The relationship between expressways and sources of
employment is thus of considerable importance. Within the City there
are 330 manufacturing firms employing more than 40 employees. To-
gether these firms employ a total of about 75,000 persons. Eighty-six of
these firms employing 16,600 persons lie within 14 mile of the Northern
Route; 193 firms employing 34,200 persons lie within 15 mile of the
Harbor Route.

The central business district with approximately 95,000 employees
represents the largest single concentration of employment in the metro-
politan area. After making allowance for the effect of Charles Center on
employment distribution, the center of central business district employ-
ment will be virtually at Baltimore and Charles Streets. This point is
3 blocks from the Harbor Route; 10 blocks from the Northern Route.

51

While nearly all commercial and industrial firms are dependent upon
the movement of goods, the degree of dependency is greater for some
firms than for others. A study was made of certain types of firms which
by their nature are highly dependent upon their ability to distribute goods
within the metropolitan area or between Baltimore and other cities.

Of the 115 firms within the City engaged in intercity trucking 21
are located within 14 mile of the Northern Route; 70 within 14 mile of
the Harbor Route.?

A selection was made of a number of the more important firms en-
gaged in distribution within the metropolitan area. The location of each
of these firms was then checked in relationship to the two routes. The
results are shown in Table 1. It will be noticed that 114 of the firms are
within 14 mile of the Harbor Route while only 65 of the firms are within
15 mile of the Northern Route. Furthermore, the Harbor Route scores
higher for each category within the Table except that of movers and storers.

Also important to the economic life of the city and as generators of
truck traffic are the major points of transfer between trucks and railroads
and between trucks and ships. Thirteen such points were identified. Six
are within 15 mile of the Harbor Route; one within 14 mile of the North-
ern Route.

In the comparison presented above an effort has been made to select
factors which were both significant and also susceptible to quantitative
analysis. The results are not unexpected, however, since they are fully in
accord with the impression gained by noting on a land use map the close
proximity between the Harbor Route and the areas of major economic
importance to the City. There can be no doubt that the Harbor Route is
of greater value to the City’s economy than the Northern Route.



1 These and similar statistics quoted in this section cover firms from the western
City line to the eastern City line. Since certain sections of the two routes are
identical, certain firms may show up for each route.
